body:
I am not sure if we have to introduce the breaking change into Groovy 4 right now.
/cc @paulk-asert
This fix leads to  `-0.0f == 0.0f` being `false`, which might be unwanted.

@tomikoskinen 

This could be expected as the [Groovy documentation](https://docs.groovy-lang.org/docs/latest/html/documentation/#_identity_operator) states that *"In Groovy, it [the `==` operator] is calling equals"*, and for the `Float.equals` method the [Javadoc](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/Float.html#equals-java.lang.Object-) quite explicitly states that `-0.0f` and `0.0f` aren't compared equal.
Hmm, true. Float equality comparison should usually be done using a small threshold epsilon value, so it should not be a big deal.

@paulk-asert `0.0f == -0.0f` yields `true`, is it the expected result in Groovy? As we could see, Java yields `false`:
```java
jshell> ((Float)0.0f).equals(-0.0f)
$1 ==> false
```

The `==` operator is deemed to have _business friendly_ behavior. Equating `==` with `equals` is an over simplification. For comparable objects, comparator logic is used and `NumberAwareComparator` would become relevant for the cases mentioned here. This falls into the same category as when we compare different number types:
```
assert [false, true, 0] == [0.0f.equals(0.0d), 0.0f == 0.0d, new NumberAwareComparator().compare(0.0f, 0.0d)]
```
In summary, this PR looks good.

Actually, after further investigation, this is a breaking change but I believe now exhibits the correct behavior. We'll need to document that change and I'll create a zero-sign-agnostic comparator which anyone relying on the existing behavior (for cases which might be deemed useful behavior) could use.

We'd certainly need more testing around inherited fields/properties for such a change. I'd suggest an amendment.

The current assumption is that if the field is found it is used instead of creating a backing field. It is a little strange/cumbersome but gives wiggle room in rare circumstances, e.g. it would allow for a normal public getter/setter but with for instance a protected backing field, or a synchronized backing field but not synchronized getters/setters (albeit I don't know why you'd want that).

The main thing I'd like to detect is where two initial values are supplied (one on each of the field and property). I believe that should be an error since it would be ambiguous and which value to use is currently not specified. Currently, any initial value given for the property is ignored if a field is also found - though this is really just the current implementation - it is certainly unintuitive where no initial value is given for the field.

@PatrikTorn Are you interested in amending in this way?
Are there any performance measurements for this change?  Nothing is mentioned in the linked issue about what is taking the time or how much improvement to expect.

I tested with "project0/build.gradle" file  locally, about 10% time saved.
As for the goal, tune the performance as good as we could...
I like the name of the test ;-)
Thank you for fixing this so quickly, that will save me a lot of trouble :-)
Thanks for the PR which is merged into master. There is some follow up work we need to do. I'll clone the issue and do that work in the new issue.
I don't see any Exceptions when running the example in the linked JIRA ticket with this change.
GroovyCodeVisitorAdapter is for specific purpose, so how about making it AIC instead of standalone new class?

LGTM.
Could you add the test you mentioned?
So, we have to eliminate the lambda chaining to gain the performance? I.e. GROOVY-8991 would be broken?
It is not expected... but parser suffers from ambiguities while choosing alternatives... Maybe we have to find better way to improve the parsing performance...

> `GroovyCodeVisitorAdapter` is for specific purpose, so how about making it AIC instead of standalone new class?

What is missing from `GroovyCodeVisitor` and `CodeVisitorSupport` is the ability to override select methods of interest and restrict traversal.  If I were to create a straight AIC of `GroovyCodeVisitor` in `InvocationWriter#isThis`, the method would be hundreds of lines long and the number of imports for the class would double.  This adapter is useful outside of this particular application -- in fact I imported the implementation from groovy-eclipse.

If `InvocationWriter` was a groovy source, I could use `@AutoImplement` to get the same result.  Java requires a more verbose approach, as usual.

Any code that uses a sequence of `instanceof` checks to distinguish `ASTNode`/`Expression`/`Statement` types could instead leverage `GroovyCodeVisitorAdapter` and the visitor pattern for type dispatch.
Yep, I am happy with the `GroovyCodeVisitorAdapter` class but if we can think of a better name, I'd also be +1 for that.

the [failing job](https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/1524/checks?check_run_id=2131410713#step:5:1211) has error:

`junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Exception in constructor: testScriptMethodAnnotation (java.lang.RuntimeException: Error grabbing Grapes -- [unresolved dependency: com.jidesoft#jide-oss;[2.2.1,2.3): not found]`

it is failing only on Windows.
This dependency is available on maven Central https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.jidesoft/jide-oss/2.2.2.01
I suppose that it is a flaky test.
The Groovy 2_6_X branch is no longer active.

The release note/changelog info comes from the groovy-website repo:
https://github.com/apache/groovy-website

There is an automated changelog generated during the release process, e.g.:
http://groovy-lang.org/changelogs/changelog-3.0.7.html
You just need the appropriate fix version set in Jira which we set when we resolve an issue.

There is also a manual release notes, e.g.:
https://groovy-lang.org/releasenotes/groovy-3.0.html
Source:
https://github.com/apache/groovy-website/blob/asf-site/site/src/site/releasenotes/groovy-3.0.adoc
It is a flaky test. We know about it but haven't fixed it yet.

superseded by merging of #1504

See also: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-9981
It looks like this means that a "naïve" use of `0.0f == -0.0f` is still `true`, and that otherwise it is advisable to deliberately select the method that is intended for use. Good!

Instead of removing jcenter for Groovy 2/3, I went with moving jcenter to the last entry in the resolver chain list. As per comment in GROOVY-9989, this should minimise the impact for users who have already moved away from jcenter/bintray but not break things for users still in the progress of moving. We should remove in a later Groovy release.
Merged with some slight tweaks. Hope that's okay.
See also GROOVY-8659 (might require further work)
I merged the .muse config settings and added the comment around the currently false positive warning. Thanks!
This will be a bit tricky it seems as the Group ID has changed.

LGTM. Let's wait for the test result:
https://github.com/danielsun1106/groovy-parser/tree/GROOVY-10024

There seems to be a conflict, should we resolve that?

Edit:
This seems to be merged, thank you.
Merged - with a minor tweak for the conflict. Thanks! I suspect we will need to tweak a few other things, e.g. containsWithinBounds and perhaps time to relook at equals symmetry.
FYI, we will likely only put this in Groovy 4.

For reference, the ecj/javac equivalent for `String[] strings = m().toArray(new String[0]);` is:
```
  public static void main(java.lang.String[] args);
     0  invokestatic C.m() : java.util.List [30]
     3  iconst_0
     4  anewarray java.lang.String [18]
     7  invokeinterface java.util.List.toArray(java.lang.Object[]) : java.lang.Object[] [32] [nargs: 2]
    12  checkcast java.lang.String[] [38]
    15  astore_1 [strings]
    16  return
```

`and` and `or` work because they are binary operations so you can write "if (a.and(b))".  `not` is a unary operation semantically.  So the way you have it you could have "if (a.not())".  Are you looking for "if (not(a))"?  For that, you could supply a DGM like this:
```java
public static Boolean not(Object self, Boolean target)
```
With this, you could write "if (not(a))" and "self" would the the object that is the implicit "this", which you can ignore.

Also, when you submit for Pull Request, could you squash your commits to just one unless there is value in the separation?  The ranges change got merged without a squash and now we have over a dozen commit lines for a single feature change.
Also, you have GROOVY-9797 changes as part of this PR.

There is a commented-out `negate` method in there.  Can you delete it as part of this change?  Also, why return null?  Do `and`, `or`, `xor` and `implies` return null?  Would "!Boolean.TRUE.equals(left)" satisfy your truth table?

@eric-milles We made a new Pull Request.
Also is it intended that when you call `null.or(true)` it throws an exception, but when you call `true.or(null)` it returns true?

If you wan't "null.or(true)" to work, you would need to provide DGM "or(NullObject,Boolean)".  This may be worth creating a separate JIRA issue for consideration.  Or you can use "or" in this fashion to be null-safe "null?.or(true)".
I created a PR https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/1561 based on your current PR to tweak the check a bit.

Hi, thanks for your PR. While automatically creating the parent directories is in some ways super nice, it might also be surprising for folks familiar with current Java behavior. I think I prefer the `mkParentDirs` suggestion mentioned in the Jira issue, though I'd probably call it `createParentDirectories` these days to match the newer nio styling. Then it could also be used for `setBytes` and so on, not just `write`. What do you think about that suggestion and if you like the idea, would you feel up for altering the PR?
Suggested methods to add:
```
File ResourceGroovyMethods#createParentDirectories(File self)
Path NioExtensions#createParentDirectories(Path self, FileAttribute<?>... attrs)
```
Usage:
```
file.createParentDirectories().write(...)
path.createParentDirectories().bytes = ...
```
@xaaria What do you think? Or if you want me to progress, just let me know.

@paulk-asert We implented this (easy) feature because participating an open source project is a mandatory part of our university's course _Software Engineering Methodologies_. So to be honest I [we] have no further opinion about this.
Is there any overlap with https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-9813 and this?  Or are they satisfied out of very separate paths?
I merged and tweaked your test and modified the DGM methods as per the earlier suggestion. Thanks.
